Test of Equality of Covariances given by Srivastava 2014

Test of Equality of Covariances given by Srivastava 2014

=======

Test of Equality of Covariances given by Srivastava et al. 2014

Performs 2 and k sample equality of covariance matrix test using Srivastava et al. 2014

Value

<<<<<<< HEAD

Test Statistic for Srivastava 2014

=======

Test statistic of the hypothesis test

Details

Consider the test for the equality of covariance matrices with $$\text{H}_0: \boldsymbol{\Sigma}_1 = \boldsymbol{\Sigma}_2 = \ldots = \boldsymbol{\Sigma}_k$$ and $$\text{H}_{\text{A}}: \boldsymbol{\Sigma}_1 \neq \boldsymbol{\Sigma}_2 \neq \ldots \neq \boldsymbol{\Sigma}_k,$$ where \(\boldsymbol{\Sigma_i}\) are the population covariance matrix parameters. The sample covarinance matrix estimators, \(\textbf{S}_1, \textbf{S}_2, \ldots, \textbf{S}_i\), are distributed singular Wishart such that \(n_i\textbf{S}_i \sim W_k\left( \boldsymbol{\Sigma}_i, n_i \right)\). Then, $$T_{Sr2014} = \sum \limits^{k}_{i < j} \frac{ \left( \hat{a}_{2i_{Sr}} + \hat{a}_{2j_{Sr}} - \frac{2}{p}tr \left( S_i S_j \right) \right) ^ 2}{\theta_{Sr}}$$ where, $$\hat{a}_{2i_{Sr}} = \frac{ \left(n_i -2 \right) \left( n_i -1 \right) tr \left( \boldsymbol{V}_i^2 \right) - n \left( n - k \right) tr \left( \boldsymbol{D}^2_i \right) + tr \left( \boldsymbol{V}_i \right)^2 }{pn_i \left( n_i -1 \right) \left( n_i -2 \right) \left( n_i -3 \right) }$$ and $$\hat{a}_{2_{Sr}} = \frac{\sum \limits^k_{i = 1}(n_i -1)\hat{a}_{2i_{Sr}}}{\sum \limits^k_{i = 1}(n_i -1)}.$$ The divisor $$\theta_{Sr} = 4 \hat{a}_{2_{Sr}}^2 \left( \sum \limits_{i < j}^ k \left( \frac{1}{n_i} + \frac{1}{n_j} \right) + (k - 1)(k - 2) \sum \limits_{i = 1}^k n_i^{-2} \right)$$ is a variance term for the numerator.

References

Srivastava, M., Yanagihara, H., and Kubokawa T. (2014). Tests for covariance matrices in high dimension with less sample size. Journal of Multivariate Analysis, 130:289-309.

>>>>>>> 11e02de2acac643762276037febcbe5ff02e7758

Examples

Srivastava2014_test(iris, group = Species)
#> [1] 0.0002174325
